messages: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:58): f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092: I think I'll be at the campout as a counselor.
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (18:59): sweet - I am going to be there also -
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (18:59): how did your talk go the other day?
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (19:02): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: what are your thoughts on node.js?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:06): My talk went fine.  The two responses we got back, one very negative and one very positive, were both very accurate.  ^_^
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:06): I think node.js is interesting.  I haven't touched it, but I've read up on it a little bit.

f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (19:12): any slides from the talk? I am doing front end work on a rails project and the team is interested in nodejs for an upcoming project so I am just now becoming aware of nodejs. It seems pretty cool. And there is definitely a buzz around it.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:13): Not from me - I basically just reused my demos from my last talk.  The other dudes had some slides, though I dunno where they are.
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (19:33): f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092: if you're anywhere near NYC theres a node.js hackday/workshop this saturday
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (19:33): 7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b: I am in Cali - thanks for the heads up though :)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:35): Ooh, on that note, we've got an internal tech talk about node.js tomorrow!  Yay!
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (19:35): f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092: its only like a 7 hour flight, cmon! ;)
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (19:36): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: was that your subtle way of inviting us? ;)
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (19:36): 7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b: if only it were that easy...
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (19:38): yeah, it's only a 30 minute train ride for me and it's not that easy
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:38): f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092: I dunno if outsiders can attend.  I'll ask, if you want.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:38): Dear "I'm too lazy to read the spec right now and will instead go home"web: is there a simple way to get the DOMContentLoaded event on the document on an iframe when you set the src of the iframe (so you don't have the right document object at the point where you can set an event listener)
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (19:39): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: please ask - that would be great
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (19:52): 7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b: will any of the talks be streamed this saturday?
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (19:52): f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092: i doubt it. i think its more of a hands-on hack day
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:56): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: You were talking about ORMs coping cleanly with cases where some conditions were optional, got any code of one doing so?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:56): To ask again‚Ä¶
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:56): weeps at b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea's silence
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:10): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Either I am ignoring you or you missed "and will now go home"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:10): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: No examples, but it seems like it shouldn't be too hard
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:11): reads some documentation
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:12): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Is what you want different from using sql alchemy and doing
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:13): f = filter(foo.bar = "baz")
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:13): f = f.filter(foo.foobar = "something")
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:13): no
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:14): But I thought you meant there was a way cleaner than that :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:14): Well that seems clean relative to gluing together bits of SQL by hand depending on the conditions :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:15): (and you can probably make it look nicer if you have some good way of mapping conditions to filters)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:15): Well, in the cases where you just create an array and concat them with OR it's not massively cleaner
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:17): I tend to think that anything not involving gluing together strings is a win
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:24): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, in ISSUE-4/ISSUE-84, aren't you supposed to quote things rather than just linking to them?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:26): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: I linked, but then summarized the takeaway point from the link in my reply.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:49): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: I think your objecting could use some restatement of the argument for readers who don' already agree with robin's conclusion
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:49): *objection

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:07): notices this while reading the HTTP 1.0 spec: "Product tokens [like the User-Agent header] should be short and to the point -- use of them for advertizing or other non-essential information is explicitly forbidden. Although any token character may appear in a product-version, this token should only be used for a version identifier (i.e., successive versions of the same product should only differ in the product-version portion of the pro
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:08): I blame it all on early hackers.  Fuckers, the lot of 'em.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:09): yay for reality-based specs
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:13): Proxy Error
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:13): The proxy server received an invalid response from an upstream server.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:13): The proxy server could not handle the request POST /2002/09/wbs/40318/issues-4-84-objection-poll/.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:13): Reason: Error reading from remote server
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:13): I get that when trying to submit my objection at: http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issues-4-84-objection-poll/
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:13): pokes MikeSmith?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:14): (If that had caused me to lose my giant post that I spent like an hour writing, I'd have killed someone.)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:14): Maybe you wrote too much
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:14): I think b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 had that problem

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:15): (Browsers need more bulletproof auto-form-saving.  It's reliable enough these days that I rely on it, but just unreliable enough that it doesn't work enough times to be kind of frustrating.)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:15): suggests killing the people who haven't added a 'recover recently submitted form values' feature to browsers
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:15): $ wc ~/issue4-objection
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:15): 32  929 5804 /home/aryeh/issue4-objection
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:15): Is that too much?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:16): 13:01 < MikeSmith> if a comment is 5629 characters or longer, submitting a response will fail
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:18): (You could Twitterise your response so it fits in the limit, or post to www-archive and link to it)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:18): Seriously?  5629 is the cutoff?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:19): shrugs

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:19): Wikipedia used to have a problem where some browsers wouldn't handle text boxes properly if they had 32 KB or more of text, but that's at least a vaguely comprehensible number.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:20): is used to Twitterizing git commit summaries so the first line is 50 characters or less, so that should be no big deal to do
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:22): Well, seems like it worked.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:22): I wasn't too far over, so no big deal.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:26): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: I had the same problem. MikeSmith instructed me to post to www-archive and point from the survey to www-archive
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:26): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, I was only a couple hundred bytes over, so I just shortened it a bit.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:40): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Maybe the real limit is 8192 or something, but a whole load of extra bytes are added somewhere?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:40): Would make sense.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:40): 8192 is still kinda radom though
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:41): I'm guessing the system wasn't really stress-tested so much prior to the HTMLWG "everyone is a member" philosophy.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:41): With this poll it's more like "everyone is Alexander Pope"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (21:42): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: if you can't make your response short enough, I you can always mail it to www-archive and post a link
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:42): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, it's okay, I just shortened it a bit.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:43): decides that Pope was not quite who he had in mind
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:43): Although if anyone does write their response in verse form, I shall be impressed
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:44): Possibly the chairs less so :)
